title: Strings
description: BPL strings are null-terminated character arrays following C conventions. String literals are immutable and stored in read-only memory. The string type is an alias for char*, enabling pointer operations. Standard C library functions (strlen, strcpy, strcmp, strcat) work with BPL strings. String comparison with == compares pointers, not content - use strcmp for content comparison. Strings are not automatically managed, so heap-allocated strings must be manually freed. This example demonstrates string literals, standard string functions, concatenation, and comparison.
